conclusion: When a point light is moved sideways, light rays arrive from a different horizontal direction.
A shadow is always cast on the side opposite the light, so when the lamp slides to the right every shadow slides to the left.

The height of the lamp has not changed, so the vertical angle of the rays (and therefore the overall length of each shadow measured away from its object) is almost unchanged; only the horizontal position and a small horizontal stretch change.
Shadow A corresponds to the bird-cage.
Shadow A's position shifts to the left of the cage instead of being nearly underneath it.
Shadow A's size/shape becomes a little wider in the left-right direction due to the cage's tall and symmetrical structure.
Shadow B corresponds to the spinning-top/rod-like object.
Shadow B's position flips to the left of the object; the long thin streak that is now on the right rotates to the left.
Shadow B's size/shape remains the longest of the three because the object is tall and thin; its length may even increase slightly because the light is hitting it more sideways.
Shadow B's orientation changes, with the 'pointer' that currently leans down-right leaning down-left after the move.
Shadow C corresponds to the drumstick.
Shadow C's position slides left, following the same rule as the other shadows.
Shadow C's size/shape remains almost the same overall footprint because the drumstick is short; only a slight horizontal stretching and leftward displacement are noticeable.
Brightness (how dark each patch looks) does not change appreciably because the lampâ€™s power and height remain the same.
All three shadows move to the left because the light moves to the right.
The lengths of the shadows are nearly unchanged; only a small horizontal stretching occurs.
Shadow A becomes a little wider but otherwise similar.
Shadow B swings to the left and may lengthen slightly, remaining the longest.
Shadow C simply slides left with barely any change in size.
